did.abstract: Frank Pollatsek was a union activist who testified before the Smith Committee during World War II due to his advocacy for the Fair Employment Practices Commission (FEPC). Pollatsek (along with the Recruiting and Manning Organization, a part of the larger War Shipping Administration where he worked,) was investigated by the Smith Committee, led by Rep. Howard W. Smith (D-VA), author of the 1940 Smith Act. The investigation focused on Pollatsek's commitments to the FEPC, in particular the argument that Black and white sailors should have equal treatment by their employer. The Frank Pollatsek Papers (1941-1945) consist of transcripts of testimonies by Frank Pollatsek and other individuals before the Smith Committee and correspondence with civil rights leaders and organizations. Noted correspondents include Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. and the NAACP, with whom Pollatsek forged alliances in support for the FEPC and in support of his defense in front of the Smith Committee. The collection documents the period of American politics just before the rise of McCarthyism and demonstrates how, even as World War II was being fought, anti-communist movements were intensifying.
